Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the immediate steps he intends to take to implement the recommendations of the Murphy report on adult education.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Following publication of the report Adult Education in Ireland views were sought from some 100 interested agencies and organisations concerning the various recommendations contained in the report. Views are still awaited from some of the organisations but I anticipate that they will be received in the near future. The question of the appropriate measures to be taken for the future expansion of the adult education programme will be examined in the light of the recommendations contained in the report and the views received from the various interested groups.

Does the Minister agree with the idea in the Murphy report that finance must come from his Department for the development of adult education or does he adhere to the belief that adult education should pay for itself?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I decline to answer that question because it would force me to make a decision now on something which has not yet been decided.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Examination Leaks.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the manner in which his Department dealt with the answer papers affected by the examination leaks in summer 1974; and whether the candidates were completely satisfied in each case.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I would refer the Deputy to my reply to the question by him on 27th June, 1974, regarding this matter. The procedure outlined in the third paragraph of the reply was followed in the case of the subjects concerned.
There was no increase in the number of applications for reassessment of grades in these subjects as compared with previous years.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Community Schools Financing.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the steps he is taking to finance adequately the existing community schools.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Each school is given a budget designed to cover normal school running costs apart from salaries of whole-time teachers and capital expenditure which are paid direct by my Department.

MainHeading.P: This budget is calculated in accordance with information available to my Department regarding costs of administration, part-time and non-teaching staff, class materials, heating, lighting and all other necessary items of expenditure.

Speaker.P: Has the Minister taken any steps to make up for the rise in the cost of fuel for the heating of community schools? Has the Minister made any examination of what else will suffer as a result of finance being taken up by the extra cost of heating? I have a great many supplementary questions, A Leas-Cheann Comhairle, and I am under your ruling as to whether I should ask them all together or one by one.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The best thing is for the Deputy to put his supplementaries and, if the Minister feels he would like the Deputy to repeat the questions, then the Deputy may repeat them.
I will rest satisfied with the ones I have asked already.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The budget submitted by the various management boards would, in normal circumstances, take account of these heating requirements and I am quite satisfied they do.

Would the Minister state if he is satisfied that slashing the budget of one community school from £53,000 to £35,000 leaves the committee of management with a feasible proposition? Is he aware that the headmaster of the Tallaght community school said he may have to close down during the year because of lack of finance?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I am not impressed by the public statements of those who, when their original estimates, which are sometimes inflated, are not met accuse me of slashing budgets and so forth. We keep all these things under consideration and in each case we have given them adequate finance to carry on the functions of the school.

Will the Minister agree with me that adult education participation and participation in the amenities of the sports complexes at the community school were cardinal points when the community schools were launched?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Yes.
Would the Minister say whether he has provided any money whatsoever for those two important aspects of the community schools?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The moneys for these have been provided. If the Deputy is referring to unsolved difficulties about swimming pools, perhaps he would wait for a further question which deals with this matter.
The part of my supplementary question about adult education has not been dealt with.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: As I understand it, the funds for adult education in these community schools are adequate for the purposes for which they were intended.

One final supplementary. When the Minister slashed the budget in the case of a number of community schools why did he not consult with the board of management, which has been democratically selected, and why was this ukase issued from the Department without any consultation whatsoever?

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: That is a separate question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The Deputy should realise that what has happened is there has been a change in the accounting system from an imprest system to a budgetary system and, if he understands this, he will understand what happened.
I understand the community schools are starved of finance.

When the Minister's party were in Opposition is it not well known that their opposition to community schools was very evident by their questioning here and is it not fair to say that the Minister is trying to sabotage the community schools scheme? Is that not the reality and is the Minister not effectively motivated by class-consciousness in his approach to education generally?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The three points made by the Deputy are wrong.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Teachers' Dispute.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the steps he intends to take to settle the dispute with the Teachers Union of Ireland which has resulted in the curtailment of teaching hours.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I had a meeting with representatives of the managerial and teaching associations on 6th November and a further meeting with a deputation from the Irish Vocational Educational Association on 25th November.
Because I am awaiting certain information arising out of the latter meeting I do not deem it appropriate to say anything further on the matter just now.
From the tone of the Minister's reply, am I to take it we are near a solution to this very grave problem?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The Minister always hopes that solutions are at hand.
It is a case of fiddling while Rome is burning, is it not?

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - European Studies.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the financial support that is available for post-graduate degrees in European studies.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: There is no distinction between the support available for post-graduate degrees in European Studies and other branches of the Humanities in Irish Universities. Courses are financed from the general university recurrent grants and funds are not earmarked for particular faculties.

MainHeading.P: The European Communities offer prizes and grants for University these which make an important and original contribution to the knowledge of problems relating to European integration in order to encourage young researchers in Law, Economics and Political Science, including Sociology, Social Psychology and History, to undertake studies in this area.
Irish graduates are eligible to participate in these schemes.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the extent to which this country is participating in European studies; and the extent to which the National Institute for Higher Education is contributing to these studies.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: European Studies is one of the areas in which degree and diploma courses are offered in the National Institute for Higher Education, Limerick. The institute is also a European documentation centre and as such receives copies of EEC publications. The documentation centre is intended to serve the institute and the neighbouring region.

The universities as well as being European documentation centres have a large content of European Studies in some of their courses such as History, Languages, Economics and Law. Some of the University Colleges are planning specific courses in European Studies at various levels.
There is also a European Studies content in courses such as History and Geography in post-primary schools.

Teacher-exchange schemes, scholarships for study in Europe, involvement in such European bodies as the EEC, Council of Europe and the Organisation of European Economic Development and studies of particular matters in Europe by the trade union movement, representatives of farming interests and trade bodies are other aspects of this country's learning about Europe.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Educational Co-operation.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the steps he has taken to improve communication between the educational system in Ireland and the rest of the EEC.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: In reply to a previous question from Deputy Lemass on 24th July, 1974, I had circulated with the Official Report a copy of the resolutions adopted by the Ministers for Education of the European Communities at their meeting which was held in Luxembourg last June.

The committee set up to define the priority spheres of action for future co-operation has met since and further meetings have been arranged. Ireland is represented on this committee by officers of my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Noise Pollution.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will undertake appropriate educational campaigns to stimulate public awareness of the severe dangers of noise pollution.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Noise pollution is already taken as part of the general topic of conservation in the teaching of the subjects Civics and Environmental Studies. Since European Conservation Year in particular teachers of those subjects have been encouraged to stress the importance of conservation in general. This general topic is also a feature of other school projects at present.

Is the Minister aware that there is a general unawareness of the dangers of noise pollution. The question asks him if he will undertake appropriate educational campaigns to stimulate public awareness. Will the Minister do this to get greater public awareness of the problem?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I have told the Deputy that this is already being done. The Deputy has served a useful function in drawing attention to this. I would point out that the question of noise pollution is primarily a matter for the Department of Local Government who issue rules about noise levels.
My question suggests that there should be an educational campaign because, no matter what the Minister says to me, there is a general public unawareness of the problem.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The teachers do this in the subjects I have mentioned. The Deputy has now drawn attention to it and I hope that some extra effort may be put into it on foot of his question.
So the answer is “No”?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: It is not “No”. I have told the Deputy it is done in those subjects.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - County Dublin School.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he is aware of the need for a new school for second-level students in the Dalkey/Killiney area, County Dublin; and, if it is his intention to provide such a school, where he intends to locate it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The Dublin advisory council on second-level school accommodation requirements is at present investigating the future needs of the areas of Dún Laoghaire, Dalkey, Sallynoggin, Cabinteely and Ballybrack and will make a recommendation to me in due course in this matter. A decision in relation to the question of the provision of a new school will be made without avoidable delay after receipt of the recommendation from the advisory council.

Can the Minister say when this Dublin advisory council will report to him? Has he put a time limit on the production of the report? Is it hoped that the report will be produced within a year, or six months, or three months?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I cannot say when it will be produced. There is no unavoidable delay in these matters. We keep after them and they are not usually dilatory in supplying these reports.
I appreciate that they are not dilatory. In view of the urgency of the problem, can the Minister say when the Dublin advisory council will produce this report to him?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Within a matter of months, I should imagine.
Is the Minister aware that there is a serious hazardous transport problem for pupils leaving that area at the moment?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: If the Deputy is referring to the Kilternan area, I understand the problem. I was personally involved in trying to solve it.
Has the Minister solved it?

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Greenhills (Dublin) School.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he is aware of the serious position which exists at Saint Paul's Secondary School, Greenhills, Dublin, due to lack of accommodation; and if he will indicate the present position of plans for the proposed permanent extension to this school.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: My Department have approved plans to extend the permanent capacity of this school to 800 places.
It is anticipated that examination of costings and draft lay-out plans will be completed by mid-December, 1974, and that building work may commence before the end of 1975.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Ringsend (Dublin) School.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the date in 1975 on which the new school building programme will commence at the Technical School, Ringsend, Dublin.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Planning for the erection of a new vocational school at Ringsend is in hands and the vocational education committee are to provide a draft schedule of accommodation as soon as possible. I am not yet in a position to give a precise date for the commencement of the building work.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Dún Laoghaire Nautical College.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the plans, if any, there are to retain the Nautical College at Dún Laoghaire; and if he will make a general statement in the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: There are no plans, as far as my Department are concerned, to retain the Nautical College at Dún Laoghaire. I have made arrangements to provide nautical training in the new Regional Technical College in Cork.

The Minister has not been fulsome in his reply to my question. He is aware that, arising out of representations by myself and other Deputies in the constituency, he is maintaining the Nautical College in Dún Laoghaire until September, 1975. Is not that correct?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Yes.

Could the Minister not given an adequate reply to my he not agree that here we have on the east coast a ready-made situation for a nautical college and for the extension of sea knowledge generally? Why does the Minister want to close this college down? We have a tremendous history of sea-faring on the east coast. I do not wish in any way to denigrate or underrate the contribution made by the Cork College. There is a need for that in Cork, too. I would especially appeal to the Minister to retain this Nautical College in Dún Laoghaire. I think the Taoiseach would agree with me on that, if that is any help to the Minister.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The Irish Nautical College in Dún Laoghaire is a private institution run by a committee of management composed of representatives of shipping interests. Under the Vocational Act, the college receives an annual maintenance grant from the Department of Education in connection with the courses of technical education provided by it. It is proposed to cease payment of the maintenance grant to the Nautical College on the transfer to the Cork Regional Technical College. If the Nautical College in Dún Laoghaire can make financial arrangements with any other agency to carry on without the aid of the Department's grant, it will be a matter for the committee of management to decide whether the college should continue to operate in some form in Dún Laoghaire.
It is a disgrace.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The Department are not legally bound to make a maintenance grant to the college. They do so merely in the furtherance of technical education.

Would the Minister not agree with the people who approached Deputy Andrews and myself on this subject that it is imposing a severe hardship on people who have an interest in the sea and need this training to have to go down to Cork for it?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: There is no need for the Irish Nautical College in Dún Laoghaire to cease functioning if it can run under its own steam and does not ask the Department of Education for funds.
I do not know how this horse can live everywhere without grass.
What type of thinking suggests that the Minister should withdraw the grant from the Nautical College?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I can answer that simply.

Would the Minister agree that the vocational educational committee in Dún Laoghaire, which contains a fair cross-section of the community and represents the political parties in the community, want the Nautical College retained and want the grant from the Department to be continued to ensure its retention?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The Deputy may be interested to know that I am agreeing with the decision made by the previous Administration on foot of a survey set up in 1968 and reporting in 1969.

I am concerned with the existence of the Nautical College in Dún Laoghaire. It is fair to say that all the political parties want it to remain there. I could not care less about the previous decision. The Minister is trying to play politics with this. That is a matter for himself, and for his own conscience. I am asking him to ensure that the Nautical College in Dún Laoghaire will continue to be paid the grant by the Department and that it will be developed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Funds are not sufficiently available to allow us to duplicate facilities in many places. Since arrangements are being made for nautical training in the Regional Technical College in Cork, I do not see why we should duplicate these facilities in Dún Laoghaire. I would invite Deputies to realise that the college in Dún Laoghaire may continue to operate provided it regulates its own affairs.

Is the Minister saying that the money which will be spent in Cork will be adequate considering the economic importance of harvesting the sea? Is the Minister aware that all administrations regarded this as very important and that all academic institutions have encouraged it?

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle Denis Francis Jones
Speaker.P: The Deputy is widening the question.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I can assure the Deputy that the provision made in Cork will be adequate.
I do not believe it.
What about the staff of the college?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The staff have been offered employment in the marine department of the new Regional Technical College in Cork on conditions not less favourable than these they now enjoy in Dún Laoghaire.

Would the Minister not agree that there is great hardship involved in transferring these families from one area to another? Indeed, there is a social problem. The Minister has an obligation in the context of social justice to maintain this Nautical College in Dún Laoghaire.
The Minister should reconsider it. Only a few pounds are involved.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Only last week we made arrangements between the Department and the various interests involved to secure the smooth transfer of these facilities to Cork.
Would the Minister not reconsider it?
It will kill interest in the area.
It is a disgraceful situation. However, the matter will be pursued further. The Taoiseach will not be too happy about it.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Cabinteely (Dublin) School.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when it is intended to provide the proposed community school for Cabinteely, County Dublin; when will it become operative; and the number of pupils and staff to be contained within the complex.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: It is expected that the new community school in Cabinteely will commence operation in September, 1975. The school will be developed to cater for 800 pupils.
The staffing of the school will be in accordance with the usual regulations in regard to pupil-teacher ratio for community schools and voluntary secondary schools.
Could the Minister give us the pupil-teacher ratio?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: One to 20.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - County Dublin Swimming Pools.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he proposes to make the swimming pools at Tallaght and Blanchardstown Community Schools, County Dublin, available to the public; and, if so, when the pools will be available for such use.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The intention is to make these swimming pools available to the public. Discussions are at present proceeding between the Department of Education and the Dublin County Council with a view to arriving at agreement on the appropriate arrangements to be made for this purpose.

Discussions have been taking place for some time between the Minister's Department and council officials. Is the Minister in a position to say what progress has been made? This matter has been outstanding for a long time. The swimming pools are lying idle and the children of the two areas are badly in need of swimming pools. Can the Minister say when the swimming pools will be made available to the public?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: They will be available to the public when Dublin County Council make appropriate arrangements with the Department of Education for the financing of the complex.

Is there not a problem with regard to financing the payment of the staff there? Is the Department of Education not anxious that Dublin County Council meet these requirements? Surely the Department of Education have some responsibility in this matter?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The Department of Education have responsibility for certain aspects of the complex.
Would the Minister like to say precisely at what stage are the negotiations between his Department and Dublin County Council?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Some weeks ago we invited the manager of Dublin County Council to come in and discuss the matter with us. The matter has progressed but not to my total satisfaction.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Vocational Committees Borrowing.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if his Department have informed vocational education committees that they should borrow privately to meet their essential requirements until the next budget.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: My Department have not so informed vocational education committees.

MainHeading.P: The Deputy may, however, have in mind the established practice whereby committees may raise finance by way of temporary short-term loans. In accordance with normal procedure some committees have been so authorised in respect of the period ending 31st December, 1974, where the circumstances warrant such action.

Speaker.P: My information is that committees were asked to borrow privately.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Not privately.
The committees themselves?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: They are empowered under the Vocational Act, 1930, to borrow by means of over-draft from the banks or otherwise for general purposes or by means of long-term loans for capital work.
I take it that no committee were asked to borrow privately?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Not privately in the sense that they would be doing so——
Does the Minister know what I mean by “privately”?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: Yes, if they are doing it under the section——

They might get it in their own name. This is what I mean. I take it from the Minister's answer that no such direction was given to any committee. I accept his word, but it seems a contradiction of my information.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: The Deputy may be seeking clarification of established practice whereby pending receipt of a long-term loan the committee may be seeking bridging finance for their treasurer to defray urgent or unforeseen expenditure on capital undertakings.

My information is that bridging loans were guaranteed by the Department and no private borrowing was ever asked of committees. I may be wrong; I accept the Minister's word that no vocational education committee was authorised to borrow privately.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: In most cases they look to the Local Loans Fund to finance capital undertaking. What tends to happen towards the end of the financial year is that applications for loan instalments exceed the amount which the local loans office may be authorised to pay in a particular time. It is usual in these circumstances to authorise certain committees, those with substantial building works in progress or needing deposits for private purchases, to raise with their treasurers short-term or bridging finance to meet their commitments. Bridging finance may also be necessary to enable committees to undertake unforeseen emergency capital works or to meet price increases on building projects for which specific provision may not have been made in the financial programme for a particular year. This must be done under section 49 or section 50 of the Act.
Will the Minister agree that that was private borrowing?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I do not agree that it is private borrowing.
It is departing from general practice.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: It is not. This has been the practice over the years.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - UCG Courses.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if his attention has been drawn to reports (details supplied) to the effect that due to lack of finance there is a major cut-back in the number of courses at UCG; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I am not aware that there is any cut-back in the number of courses as UCG. I have been advised by an tÚdarás um Ard-Oideachas that the UCG accounts for the current financial period show a substantial deficit arising mainly from salary and wage increases. Arrangements to meet the deficit are at present under consideration.
May I take it that there will be no cut-back?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I cannot give the Deputy that undertaking since I am not in charge.
Serious consideration has been given to this in Galway. Then I may take it that there will be no cut-back?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: I cannot give the Deputy that guarantee since I am not in a position to do so.
Would the Minister agree to An tÚdarás's suggestion that the university colleges are under-financed and need an increase in the grants for fees immediately?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: An tÚdarás um Ard-Oideachas, like many other bodies, are stating that they are under-financed. I deal with these matters when the cases are put to me. I do not consider they are under-financed given the financial stringency under which we are operating at the moment.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Ballaghaderreen School Inquiry.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Flanagan Mr. S. Flanagan
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if, in respect of a reply to a written question recently, he will explain why the inquiry into the dispute concerning Ballaghaderreen Vocational School, County Roscommon, has not been pursued; and why promises made in regard to the completion of such an inquiry have not been fulfilled thereby permitting a situation deleterious to the pupils and staff involved to continue for 14 months.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke

As the matter is, therefore, sub judice it would be inappropriate for me to comment further at this stage.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - School Closures.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if it is his intention to close all schools that have an attendance of less than 22 pupils; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: In normal circumstances as the opportunity offers the educational interests of the children may require that recognition be withdrawn from a one-teacher school and suitable arrangements made for its amalgamation with another school to form a larger educational unit.

In connection with a proposal for the amalgamation of schools in any area the particular circumstances of the individual school receive the fullest consideration and there is full consultation with the local interests involved before final decisions are taken.

The general approach to the amalgamation of small schools is indicated in my speech in the House on 23rd October, 1973 when introducing the Estimates for my Department— Official Report, Vol, 268, No. 3—and on 8th November, 1973, when closing the debate—Official Repart, Vol. 268, No. 11.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - National Teachers' Allowances.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when arrears of allowances for principal teachers and of children's allowances will be paid to national school teachers for the period 1st April to 1st October, 1974.

asked the Minister for Education when he intends to pay the allowance for a grade A post of responsibility to national school teachers for the period 1st April to 1st October, 1974; and the reason for the delay.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke
Speaker.P: With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 86 and 87 together.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the reason for the delay in deciding on the application of a person (name supplied) in County Kerry for a post-primary educational grant in respect of his daughter to which she appears to be clearly entitled.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Burke Mr. R. Burke

The pupil's father is being informed accordingly.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Ballina Sports Hall.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Social Welfare Benefits.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if he will make alterations in the system of calculating incomes for old age pension purposes in view of the fact that a person (name supplied) in County Meath who was in receipt of a disabled person's allowance from the health board was offered a lower rate of old age pension in consequence of his Department's method of income calculation.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: It has been ascertained from the health board concerned that the disabled persons maintenance allowance which the person named in the question had been receiving was terminated by the board because it transpired that means which had not been assessed against him at the time of claiming the allowance should have been taken into account. In the means assessment for old age pension purposes the means in question were taken into account. The Deputy will no doubt appreciate therefore that the method of means assessment for old age pension purposes was not an issue in this case.

asked the Minister for Social Welfare if, in the case of persons who reach the age of 70 years and fail to apply for a contributory old age pension, he will arrange to have payment of the pension back-dated to their seventieth birthday in cases in which their contributions would entitle them to payment of the pension from that date.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: As a result of improvements in the old age pension code initiated in July, 1973, the qualifying age for pension is now 68.

MainHeading.P: Existing regulations governing the claiming and payment of pension permit a pension to be paid to a claimant from the time he reaches age 68 if his claim is made within a period of three months before or three months after that date. Where it can be shown that delay in making a claim was due to circumstances beyond the person's control, retrospective payment can be made for a period of up to six months. I regard these provisions as being adequate in the circumstances to prevent hardship.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if his Department will supply the British social security authorities with the information they require concerning an application for a retirement pension by a person (name supplied) in County Meath as the delay is holding up a decision on the matter and the person concerned has not received any money from the Irish or British Departments for the past few months.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: The person concerned has no entitlement to retirement pension on his Irish insurance alone. Irish insurance can however affect his British pension entitlement under EEC regulations. Due to the fact that he has been unable to give sufficient information to enable his full Irish insurance record to be established in respect of employment which he claims to have had in this country, it has not proved possible so far for my Department to supply the British authorities with the information they require. They are being informed of the position and are being requested to examine his pension entitlement on the basis of his British insurance. Inquiries necessary to establish his full Irish contribution position are being continued.

asked the Minister for Social Welfare when disability benefit will be paid to a person (name supplied) in County Meath who first applied on 29th August, 1974; and the reason for the delay in dealing with this case.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: The person referred to by the Deputy is not entitled to disability benefit on his claim as he does not satisfy the contribution condition which requires a claimant to have a minimum of 26 contributions paid or credited in the contribution year governing his claim. The claimant was insurably employed for only ten weeks in the period January to December, 1973, which is the contribution year governing his claim.

Although he was incapable of work from 26th August, 1974, the claim was not received in the Department until 23rd September, 1974, and at that date there was no information available regarding his employment in 1973. Inquiries then made disclosed insurable employment for only ten weeks and contributions due were collected.

asked the Minister for Social Welfare the manner in which he proposes to allocate the money collected by way of social welfare contributions from persons in higher income groups in view of the fact that they are not at present eligible for social welfare benefits or benefits under the Health Acts; and if he will refund the money to these persons until such time as they may qualify for such benefits.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: The Deputy appears to be under a misapprehension concerning the position of persons in higher income groups who are paying social insurance contributions. Such persons are in fact generally eligible for social welfare benefits in the same way as other insured workers. There are however some who, because they became insured too late in life, will not qualify for retirement or contributory old age pensions. The element appropriate to these pensions in their share of the social insurance contribution is refundable.

MainHeading.P: Employees not eligible for hospital services under the Health Acts do not contribute any element in their total weekly social insurance contribution in respect of health services. In such cases the weekly health contribution falls on the employer who, as already announced, may claim a refund of the amount involved at intervals to suit his convenience.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if he will arrange to to increase the rate of unemployment assistance, which is 25p per week at present, payable to a fisherman (name supplied) in County Meath who has been unemployed since the end of the fishing season.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: The unemployment assistance rate of 25p per week in this case derives from a decision of a deciding officer assessing the person's means at £5.80 per week. The person has appealed against this decision and he will be notified of the outcome as soon as the appeals officer has given his decision in the light of the result of further inquiries which have been directed by him.

MainHeading.P: The Deputy will appreciate that the determination of means for the purposes of the Unemployment Assistance Acts is a matter for statutory deciding officers or appeals officers and that neither the Minister nor anyone else can give instructions to those officers in the exercise of that function.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Issue of Children's Allowance Book.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare when a children's allowance book will be issued to a person (name supplied) in County Meath in respect of her child who was born in July, 1974; and the reason for the delay in dealing with this case.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. Corish) Brendan Corish
Speaker.P: A children's allowance book was sent in the usual way by post to the person concerned on 14th August, 1974. It now transpires however that the local post office, which is also the office of payment for that person's children's allowance, held the book for collection instead of having is delivered to the addressee. A replacement book and a payable order in respect of arrears have now been sent to the person concerned.
